VARSITY FALLS BEFORE CHAPTER OF TAU BETA PI STUMP WINS ADAMS CONORGANIZED AT HOPKINS.
HEAVY HITTING W.S. L.
TEST.
TEAM
Eleven Runs in Last Two Innings Cost
Hopkins Fifth Game of Season—
Three Hurlers Unable to Subdue Generals Who Win
by 18-7 Score.

A large crowd present at Homewood last Saturday afternoon witnessed the defeat of the Varsity
Baseball Team by Washington
and Lee to the tune of 18 to 7.
The game developed into an oldfashioned swatfest from the very ,
offset, runs being scored in every
inning except the second.and sixth,
in both of which one team filled
the sacks before the third man was
sent clown.
The two teams used a total of
five twirlers, none of whom could
truthfully be said to have been effective, since 32 bingles and 14
passes were allowed by them.
Tucker, starting for Hopkins,
weathered the storm until his wildness caused his relief in the fifth
by Owings who was forced to give
way to Marchetti in the eighth.
Walker opened'the game on the
mound for the . visitors, but was
touched up in such a lively manner that he was derricked in the
fourth stanza.
The game progressed evenly until the last two innings, when hits,.
ranging from beaten-out bunts to
clouts to the centerfield fence, netted the Generals a total of 11 runs,
sufficient to takes the heart out of
the Hopkins supporters.
Burke was the batting star of
the contest, hitting safely each of
his four times at bat, while Hayter
and Knecht brought joy to the
home team's rooters by their circuit clouts. "Mike" Strouse, replacing Sharretts at third, was by
far Hopkins' defensive star, his
clever and brainy fielding doing
much to hold the infield together.

PRICE 10 CENTS

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 19, 1921

4

Engineering Society Corresponding To
Phi Beta Kappa—Twenty-two Men
Admitted As Charter Members.

On Friday, April 8, a chapter of
Tau Beta Pi, a national honorary
fraternity composed of students of
the highest scholarship attainments in leading engineering
schools of the country, was established at Hopkins by Prof. R. C.
Matthews. A banquet at the Hopkins Club followed, at which the
following officers were elected:
President, C. F. Chisholm; vicepresident, M. E. Scheidt; sec'etaries, M. Cohen and A. R. Dixon;
treasurer, Louis Well; cataloguer,
W. Rupp; correspondent, L. E.
Biemiller.
Tau Beta Pi was originated at
Lehigh University in 1889 to fill
the place of Phi Beta Kappa in the
engineering schools by Professor
Williams of that institution. It
now consists of over 30 chapters
and it is a signal honor to Hopkins to have this fraternity installed here. The authorities of
the enginering department are
highly pleased over being admitted
to Tau Beta Pi as it means national recognition of the high
standards reached by them in the
engineering education facilities developed at Homewood. Member:
ship in the fraternity is bared principally on scholastic attainments
in technical studies, but personality, leadership and general
character are also taken into account, which makes it more exclusive than Phi Beta Kappa.
The first quarter of the class
standing highest in their studies
are eligible to the fraternity, the
men being chosen in two sections.
In the middle of their junior year
one-eighth of the class may be
chosen and then at the end of the
junior year the remaining eighth
is eligible.
The men elected to
inembership were Senior of 1920—
L. G. Smith, K. H. Andrae, N. N,
Holland, F. W. Herring, A. R.
Spartana, H. B. Show, E. S.
Dougherty—Seniors of 1921—J.
F. Birkmeyer, A. R. Dixon, T. F.
Hubbard, Walter Rupp, D. T. Rosenthal, M. E. Scheidt, L. W. Call,
Maurice Cohen, W. W. Collier, L.
E. Biemiller, Arthur Shapiro,
Louis Weil, Carrol Stansbury, C.
F. Chisholm, A. V. D. Smith and
G. W. Keen.

TICKETS.

Defeats Three Other Entrants In Annual Competition—Recites Speech
By Curtis On "The Immigration Problem."

After a deliberation of 25 minutes the judges of this year's
Adams contest in public speaking
awarded the medal to John F.
Stump. The contest , was held in
the C. E. Hall at the weekly assembly on Thursday, April 14.
Dr. French introduced the ,subject, explaining the origin and
purpose of the contest, 'stating
that such a contest has taken place
each year for a number of years.
Dr. Adams conceived the Idea and
provided a fund for a medal,to be
given each year to the best orator
in the public speaking classes. at
Hopkins. The purpose of the contest is to advance student inteiest
in oratory and public speaking.
The speakers were introduced by
Dr. French, who said that in order
to insure perfect fairness each
would make his address in the
order which. he had previously
drawn by lot.
The first speaker, Klotz, made
a fine speech. His clear-cut, expressive delivery and his absolute
coolness made a strong impression
on the audience, and his effOrts
were received with a great deal of
applause; The subject of his •address was "The Cuban Situation
Prior to the Spanish-American
War."
Stump, the second speaker,
spoke on "The Immigration Problem," using part of a speech made
by Mr. Curtis on that subject. In
this address the speaker made
use of apparently all the means
within the bounds of expression,
by inflection of voice, by gesture
and by loud-sounding appeal to
his -audience. Stump held his
hearers in rapt attention and admiration throughout the whole
speech.
The next speaker, S. B. Rosenfeld, gave a portion of Woodrow
Wilson's Flag Day address. His
delivery was excellent, but perhaps a trifle too blase or lifeless
at the start. After a• few introductory sentences, however, he
awakened to his task and made a
very fine address, which was well
received by the entire assembly. .
W. K. Smith was the next and
last speaker. He spoke on the
"Responsibilities of War," from.
a speech by the New England
Minister Chaney. His coolness,
force of expression and masterful-delivery must have made him"
a strong contender for the prize.
The judges of the contest were
Dr. W. P. Mustard, Mr. T. R.
Ball and Mr. A: L. Hammond.

LACROSSE TEAM WINS FROM
ARMY IN EXTRA PERIOD
Murphy Shoots Deciding Goal Near
' End of Third Period — West
Pointers Make Remarkable
Showing for New
Team.

In a hard-fought game Hopkins defeated the Army in lacrosse
at West Point on Saturday. At
the end of the game the score
stood 2 to 2. An extra period of
10 minutes was started, and nine
minutes of this was played to a
standsill when Murphy shot the
deciding goal in the last minute
of play. The game was the first
on the schedule for the Army, and,
as it is their first year at lacrosse,
they show wonderful possibilities
of developing a championship
team. They have a big, fighting
team, in perfect physical condition, and the men seem to know a
lot more about the game than
would be supposed at thik stage of
the season. The fact that a brandnew team was able to play a team
of Hopkins' caliber to a standstill
brands them as contenders for the
intercollegiate title in years to
come.
Hopkins presented an altered
attack from that which played in
the Alumni game last• week.
Coady displaced Huey at third attack, while Parsons played the
whole game at second attack.
Whether this was responsible for
the low score is not known, but it
is evident that the coaches are experimenting with all the material
in hopes of getting a winning combination for the hard games to
come. The defense is good, one
that knows the game and one that
will probably take the measure of
any attack which will be met this
year, but the attacks must be
strengthened, their stockwork and
fighting qualities improved.
Griffin scored for Hopkins in the
first period, while Myer of Army
was able to get one past Benedict.
In the second half the Army scored
again on a shot by Coates. Bauernschmidth, who can usually be
depended upon for a goal, tied the
score at two all by a pretty shot
past Greene, the Army goalkeeper.
An extra period was then started,
and Murphy, in the last minute of
play, shot the goal that won.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 19, 1921

3

SENIORS OUTLINE CLASS.. RACQUET TO BE GIVEN TO PREPARATIONS FOR GRADS' GEOLOGISTS ENJOY ANNUAL
WEEK ACTIVITIES.
WINNER OF TENNIS
TRIP.
NUMBER NOW UNDER WAY.
TOURNEY.
Banquet, Prom, Class Day Exercises,
Bacculaureate Services and Conferring of Degrees Constitute Program.

4

An outline of the activities for
Senior week were formulated at a
meeting of the 1921 class,on Fri;
day in the M. E. lecture room. Examinations are all to be over Monday, June 13, and it is predicted
that from then until Friday night,
when the prom will be held, the
men will all be out looking for
jobs to occupy them during the
summer or permanently. The
original plan suggested Saturday
night for the banquet but by the
vote of a large majority it was
changed to Monday night. On
Sunday every Senior will attend
the bacculaureate service at one
of the city's best churches and will
be in cap and gown if the old tradition is adhered to. On Monday
the class day exercises are scheduled at 4 o'clock and the banquet
at 8. The conferring of degrees
will take place at 4 o'clock on
Tuesday afternoon in the Lyric.
The definite arrangements of the
activities on the program are in
the hands of several committees:
For the prom, C. W. Perkins,
chairman; Holmes Boyd and Bartus Trew ; for the banquet, E. R.
Taylor, chairman; J. Benson and
N. C. Keyes; for class day exercises, C. I. T. Gould, chairman;
R. L. Bowers, Earle, D. S. Mossom, R. G. Heiner and Harold
Reed.
The fee of $5 for the banquet
collected as part of the budget will
assure a hundred per cent. attendance and will make the last
social meeting of the graduating
class one long to be remembered.
The prom will be paid for by subscription from each man who attends. R. K. Mulliken and Gould
are working with the committee to
prepare some unique features for
class day exercises which will have
the same general plan as those
conducted so,excellently by Harry
Morriss last year.
A report of the treasurer, F. L.
Hubbard, shows that out of the
class of 124 members 95 have paid
the whole amount ($27) of dues,
13 have made part payments and
16, for some reason or other, have
paid nothing. Expenditures so
far have been $10 to the Student
Council and $1,408 to the Hullabaloo. Hubbard was also authorized to have his design of the class
banner made up in time for the
class exercises. A committee was
then appointed to work on some
appropriate memorial for the class
to give the university.
ZIONIST SOCIETY.

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society will be addressed on Tuesday, April 19, in Room 110, M. E.
Building, by Dr. Max Margolis, a
professor at Dropsie College and a
most interesting speaker. The
public is cordially invited.

Donation Of Local Sporting Goods Concern—Tournament Begun With
Over Forty Candidates
Participating.

To Be Great Send-off For Seniors—Positions On Black and Blue Jay
Open To Candidates.

The tennis tournament, which
was announced several weeks ago,
is now well under way. In response to the call for candidates
42 names were turned in. Although not as large a number as
last year, this is a very good showing considering the comparatively
early date for tennis activity.
The drawings were made and
first-match notices sent out in time
to start April 8, but due to poor
weather conditions the first match
was not played until April 14. In
this Eric Jacobsen was defeated
by Bosley Hiss. With favorable
weather conditions this week's end
should see the tournament up to
the fourth round, at least.
A set of ground rules to govern
the use of the courts is being prepared. The large number of persons wishing to use the courts and
the resulting confusion has demonstrated the need of such a set of
rules.
The Bacharach-Raisin Sporting,
Goods Company has very generously offered a $16 George Wright
racquet as a prize to the winner
of the tournament. The same firm
is further offering a considerable
reduction to J. H. U. students in
the prices of equipment.

The final edition of the Black
and Blue Jay, the Grads' number,
will appear during the latter part
of May. This issue, which is to
be devoted to Seniors and their
future, is hoped to be the best of
the year, successfully closing the
initial season of the.magazine.
In order to make the Grads'
number a real success the co-operation of the entire student-body is
prerequisite. All students are
urged to contribute and give the
Seniors a true send-off. The
Seniors are particularly requested
to aid the staff in publishing this
number, lending, as it were, the
benefits of their experience as college men.
The Black and Blue Jay board
wishes to call attention to the general spring competition for the
editorial, art and business staff
which has been recently opened. A
number of positions are available
and a splendid opportunity is
opened to men who desire to win
positions on the staff.

"Migration Of Birds" To Be Subject
Of Lecture Friday.

Dr. Harry C. Oberholser, of the
Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D. C., will address the
Scientific Club on "The Migration
of Birds" on Friday, April 22, in
the lecture room of the Mechanical Engineer Building (Room
110).
Dr. Oberholser is recognized the
world over as an authority on
bird-life, and has visited practically every part of the United
States while engaged in the extensive field work necessary to his
studies. He has recently completed a cruise on Government vessels, undertaken for the purpose
of studying the habits of sea-birds
(in particular the habits of gulls).
Dr. Oberholser has written voluminously on ornithological subjects,
and has given courses of lectures
in the American University at
Washington.
The student-body and the general public are cordially invited to
attend this lecture, which will begin promptly at 12.30 o'clock and
will end before 1 o'clock. Members of the Audubon Society are
especially urged to be present.
The Scientific Club intends in
the near future to inaugurate a
series of popular'science meetings
for the general public, in addition
to the noon meetings which cater
particularly to the interests of,the
undergraduate student. The officers will be glad to receive suggestions as to topics and speakers.

R. 0. T. C. DANCE TO BE HELD
APRIL 29.

Journey To Western Maryland Under
Leadership Of Dr. Schwartz.
Turner Goes On The Stage
With "Oh, Daddy"
Company.

According to all reports the
annual Easter geology trip was a
decided success.
Leaving the city Easter Monday the geologists arrived at Blue
Ridge Summit at 11.30 A. M.
After an unsuccessful attempt to
wreck Sprankle's busses, they
reached Pen-Mar.
In the vicinity of Key Rock the
fossil-hunters proceeded to search
for specimens. After a short time
exclamations were heard from the
neighborhood of Goldstein and
Knecht, who were seen kneeling
upon a level spot closely scanning
the marks on two small, square
fossils. Upon close examination,
however, the telltale spots and the
fervent sigh "seven" from Goldie
revealed them to be only the common everyday variety of "Alabama agates."
After digging coal, uncovering
rare specimens, and racing Dr.
Schwartz, who has held the cup
for the Cumberland derby for 10
years, the collegians retired to
Cumberland and visited the "Oh,
Daddy" show, where the chorus,
assisted by Tubby Turner, rendered "I haven't read it yet."
From there the merry-makers
retired to a "jazz hall" with most
of "Oh, Daddy." After the wrestling matches, in which Bill Randall starred, the gang "turned in."
"Goldie" when he awoke in the
morning,'
found that he had been
awarded several lemon meringue
pies—spread in a heavy film on
the lining of his suit.
However, the trip was declared
a success both geologically and
"hell-raiscally." Bubbling over
with the usual Easter trip yarns
the trippers arrived back in the
city.
To a mere student "Papa, buy
me a pool table," "Fine day for
it" and "It won't be long now"
mean nothing—but just ask a
geologist.
And don't fail to hear Steck's
song,"Whose little baby are you?"

The R. O. T. C. dance should be
a great success. It will be held
on April 29 at 9 P. M. and the
price of admission will be $2 a
couple. The affair will be informal
and uniforms will not be worn,
so the lowliest private and the
highest commissioned officer will
enter the competition on equal
terms. Tickets may be obtained
from company commanders and
from Whittington, Hall and Wilkinson. Young's orchestra has been
obtained for the occasion, so good
music and plenty of it will be
available. Major Garey, Captains
McMurray and Williams and the
officers who are visiting the university will be present. Dean and

FRESHMEN LOSE TIGHT GAME TO
CITY.

Playing errorless ball and making as many hits as their opponents the Freshmen lost to City
College at Strauss Field on Friday
by the score of 5 to 3. Inability
to profit by the breaks of the game
and some poor base-running lost
the game for the Freshmen. The
Freshmen presented a far superior team to that which played
Mount St. Josephs two "weeks ago,
and it was easy to see that they
were more than a match for City
if they had only been able to make
use of their opportunities. Ellicott
pitched for the Freshmen and
struck out eight men. He was always master of the game, except
in the first inning, when two bases
on balls and a triple by Katzenberger gave City two runs. Spinney, who pitched for City, although
a trifle wild, also twirled a good
game, having lots of steam and
plenty of curves. He scored again
for City on a drive to center by
Slingluff, making the score 3 to 0.
Ellicott brought in the Freshmen's
first run by scoring on Donnetel's
drive to left field. With two men
on the bases in the seventh it
looked like two runs for the Freshmen when Broumel hit a screeching drive over third, but Miller, of
City, made a wonder one-hand
stab, doubling his man at third.
City scored again in the eighth on
a bunt which Hutzler played foul,
and in the ninth on a wild throw
to third by •Ellicott. The Freshmen got their other two runs in the
eight and ninth also, McCubbin
driving' Goldsmith in from third
and Strouse scoring on a long fly
to left field by Broumel. For City
Katzenberger and Miller were the
stars; the former turning three
seemingly home runs into outs by
wonderful catches, and the latter
playing his position at third in fine
style and making two hits. Strouse
and Hutzler played well in the
field for the Freshmen, while Goldsmith, McCubbin and Donnetel hit
the ball hard.
The Wednesday classes on China
and Japan, under the auspices of
the Association, have proved very
popular. Both Mr. Li, of Tientsin, who is lecturing on China,
and Mr. Ibara, of Uwajima, who
is lecturing on Japan, show an infinite knowledge of their subjects.
Anyone interested in these countries as to their political, economic, commercial, educational or
religious aspects will find these
lectures most beneficial.

TRACK TEAM MEETS DISAPPOINTING REVERSE—
ALSO RAN WITH NAVY
AND DELAWARE
Hopkins' track team was outclassed in its triangular meet
with Delaware and Navy at Annapolis. The Navy piled up 60
points, Delaware collected 36
points and Hopkins received 4.
Edwards in the quarter, Somerville in the half, Wood in the high
hurdles and Aaronson in the low
hurdles scored Hopkins' 4 points
by placing third in their events.
For the rest, Navy and Delaware
presented runners too fast, weight
men to strong and jumpers too
dexterous.

Muller Addresses Field Club.

The Hopkins Field Club, which
met Wednesday, held one of the
most interesting sessions of the
term. During the first half hour
of the meeting, J. F. Muller, '24,
addressed the members of the club,
relating some of his experiences
along the Mississippi River while
doing research work with freshwater clams for the button-making
industry. The remainder of the
hour was given over to H. T.

Folger, a graduate student, who
spoke on the "Nesting Habits of
the Red Horse."
The Red Horse is a specie of
fish, somewhat resembling the
sucker, and valuable as food,
found in the Mississippi River and
streams of the Mississippi Valley.
Mr. Folger described in detail the
method of catching the Red Horse,
which is protected by law, and
then told of its nesting habits.
Both lectures were interesting and
educational, and it is hoped that

the club may be able to have more

of them.

VARSITY FALLS BEFORE CHAPTER OF TAU BETA PI STUMP WINS ADAMS CONORGANIZED AT HOPKINS.
HEAVY HITTING W.S. L.
TEST.
TEAM
Eleven Runs in Last Two Innings Cost
Hopkins Fifth Game of Season—
Three Hurlers Unable to Subdue Generals Who Win
by 18-7 Score.

A large crowd present at Homewood last Saturday afternoon witnessed the defeat of the Varsity
Baseball Team by Washington
and Lee to the tune of 18 to 7.
The game developed into an oldfashioned swatfest from the very ,
offset, runs being scored in every
inning except the second.and sixth,
in both of which one team filled
the sacks before the third man was
sent clown.
The two teams used a total of
five twirlers, none of whom could
truthfully be said to have been effective, since 32 bingles and 14
passes were allowed by them.
Tucker, starting for Hopkins,
weathered the storm until his wildness caused his relief in the fifth
by Owings who was forced to give
way to Marchetti in the eighth.
Walker opened'the game on the
mound for the . visitors, but was
touched up in such a lively manner that he was derricked in the
fourth stanza.
The game progressed evenly until the last two innings, when hits,.
ranging from beaten-out bunts to
clouts to the centerfield fence, netted the Generals a total of 11 runs,
sufficient to takes the heart out of
the Hopkins supporters.
Burke was the batting star of
the contest, hitting safely each of
his four times at bat, while Hayter
and Knecht brought joy to the
home team's rooters by their circuit clouts. "Mike" Strouse, replacing Sharretts at third, was by
far Hopkins' defensive star, his
clever and brainy fielding doing
much to hold the infield together.

BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 19, 1921

4

Engineering Society Corresponding To
Phi Beta Kappa—Twenty-two Men
Admitted As Charter Members.

On Friday, April 8, a chapter of
Tau Beta Pi, a national honorary
fraternity composed of students of
the highest scholarship attainments in leading engineering
schools of the country, was established at Hopkins by Prof. R. C.
Matthews. A banquet at the Hopkins Club followed, at which the
following officers were elected:
President, C. F. Chisholm; vicepresident, M. E. Scheidt; sec'etaries, M. Cohen and A. R. Dixon;
treasurer, Louis Well; cataloguer,
W. Rupp; correspondent, L. E.
Biemiller.
Tau Beta Pi was originated at
Lehigh University in 1889 to fill
the place of Phi Beta Kappa in the
engineering schools by Professor
Williams of that institution. It
now consists of over 30 chapters
and it is a signal honor to Hopkins to have this fraternity installed here. The authorities of
the enginering department are
highly pleased over being admitted
to Tau Beta Pi as it means national recognition of the high
standards reached by them in the
engineering education facilities developed at Homewood. Member:
ship in the fraternity is bared principally on scholastic attainments
in technical studies, but personality, leadership and general
character are also taken into account, which makes it more exclusive than Phi Beta Kappa.
The first quarter of the class
standing highest in their studies
are eligible to the fraternity, the
men being chosen in two sections.
In the middle of their junior year
one-eighth of the class may be
chosen and then at the end of the
junior year the remaining eighth
is eligible.
The men elected to
inembership were Senior of 1920—
L. G. Smith, K. H. Andrae, N. N,
Holland, F. W. Herring, A. R.
Spartana, H. B. Show, E. S.
Dougherty—Seniors of 1921—J.
F. Birkmeyer, A. R. Dixon, T. F.
Hubbard, Walter Rupp, D. T. Rosenthal, M. E. Scheidt, L. W. Call,
Maurice Cohen, W. W. Collier, L.
E. Biemiller, Arthur Shapiro,
Louis Weil, Carrol Stansbury, C.
F. Chisholm, A. V. D. Smith and
G. W. Keen.

Defeats Three Other Entrants In Annual Competition—Recites Speech
By Curtis On "The Immigration Problem."

After a deliberation of 25 minutes the judges of this year's
Adams contest in public speaking
awarded the medal to John F.
Stump. The contest , was held in
the C. E. Hall at the weekly assembly on Thursday, April 14.
Dr. French introduced the ,subject, explaining the origin and
purpose of the contest, 'stating
that such a contest has taken place
each year for a number of years.
Dr. Adams conceived the Idea and
provided a fund for a medal,to be
given each year to the best orator
in the public speaking classes. at
Hopkins. The purpose of the contest is to advance student inteiest
in oratory and public speaking.
The speakers were introduced by
Dr. French, who said that in order
to insure perfect fairness each
would make his address in the
order which. he had previously
drawn by lot.
The first speaker, Klotz, made
a fine speech. His clear-cut, expressive delivery and his absolute
coolness made a strong impression
on the audience, and his effOrts
were received with a great deal of
applause; The subject of his •address was "The Cuban Situation
Prior to the Spanish-American
War."
Stump, the second speaker,
spoke on "The Immigration Problem," using part of a speech made
by Mr. Curtis on that subject. In
this address the speaker made
use of apparently all the means
within the bounds of expression,
by inflection of voice, by gesture
and by loud-sounding appeal to
his -audience. Stump held his
hearers in rapt attention and admiration throughout the whole
speech.
The next speaker, S. B. Rosenfeld, gave a portion of Woodrow
Wilson's Flag Day address. His
delivery was excellent, but perhaps a trifle too blase or lifeless
at the start. After a• few introductory sentences, however, he
awakened to his task and made a
very fine address, which was well
received by the entire assembly. .
W. K. Smith was the next and
last speaker. He spoke on the
"Responsibilities of War," from.
a speech by the New England
Minister Chaney. His coolness,
force of expression and masterful-delivery must have made him"
a strong contender for the prize.
The judges of the contest were
Dr. W. P. Mustard, Mr. T. R.
Ball and Mr. A: L. Hammond.

LACROSSE TEAM WINS FROM
ARMY IN EXTRA PERIOD
Murphy Shoots Deciding Goal Near
' End of Third Period — West
Pointers Make Remarkable
Showing for New
Team.

In a hard-fought game Hopkins defeated the Army in lacrosse
at West Point on Saturday. At
the end of the game the score
stood 2 to 2. An extra period of
10 minutes was started, and nine
minutes of this was played to a
standsill when Murphy shot the
deciding goal in the last minute
of play. The game was the first
on the schedule for the Army, and,
as it is their first year at lacrosse,
they show wonderful possibilities
of developing a championship
team. They have a big, fighting
team, in perfect physical condition, and the men seem to know a
lot more about the game than
would be supposed at thik stage of
the season. The fact that a brandnew team was able to play a team
of Hopkins' caliber to a standstill
brands them as contenders for the
intercollegiate title in years to
come.
Hopkins presented an altered
attack from that which played in
the Alumni game last• week.
Coady displaced Huey at third attack, while Parsons played the
whole game at second attack.
Whether this was responsible for
the low score is not known, but it
is evident that the coaches are experimenting with all the material
in hopes of getting a winning combination for the hard games to
come. The defense is good, one
that knows the game and one that
will probably take the measure of
any attack which will be met this
year, but the attacks must be
strengthened, their stockwork and
fighting qualities improved.
Griffin scored for Hopkins in the
first period, while Myer of Army
was able to get one past Benedict.
In the second half the Army scored
again on a shot by Coates. Bauernschmidth, who can usually be
depended upon for a goal, tied the
score at two all by a pretty shot
past Greene, the Army goalkeeper.
An extra period was then started,
and Murphy, in the last minute of
play, shot the goal that won.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 19, 1921

3

SENIORS OUTLINE CLASS.. RACQUET TO BE GIVEN TO PREPARATIONS FOR GRADS' GEOLOGISTS ENJOY ANNUAL
WEEK ACTIVITIES.
WINNER OF TENNIS
TRIP.
NUMBER NOW UNDER WAY.
TOURNEY.
Banquet, Prom, Class Day Exercises,
Bacculaureate Services and Conferring of Degrees Constitute Program.

4

An outline of the activities for
Senior week were formulated at a
meeting of the 1921 class,on Fri;
day in the M. E. lecture room. Examinations are all to be over Monday, June 13, and it is predicted
that from then until Friday night,
when the prom will be held, the
men will all be out looking for
jobs to occupy them during the
summer or permanently. The
original plan suggested Saturday
night for the banquet but by the
vote of a large majority it was
changed to Monday night. On
Sunday every Senior will attend
the bacculaureate service at one
of the city's best churches and will
be in cap and gown if the old tradition is adhered to. On Monday
the class day exercises are scheduled at 4 o'clock and the banquet
at 8. The conferring of degrees
will take place at 4 o'clock on
Tuesday afternoon in the Lyric.
The definite arrangements of the
activities on the program are in
the hands of several committees:
For the prom, C. W. Perkins,
chairman; Holmes Boyd and Bartus Trew ; for the banquet, E. R.
Taylor, chairman; J. Benson and
N. C. Keyes; for class day exercises, C. I. T. Gould, chairman;
R. L. Bowers, Earle, D. S. Mossom, R. G. Heiner and Harold
Reed.
The fee of $5 for the banquet
collected as part of the budget will
assure a hundred per cent. attendance and will make the last
social meeting of the graduating
class one long to be remembered.
The prom will be paid for by subscription from each man who attends. R. K. Mulliken and Gould
are working with the committee to
prepare some unique features for
class day exercises which will have
the same general plan as those
conducted so,excellently by Harry
Morriss last year.
A report of the treasurer, F. L.
Hubbard, shows that out of the
class of 124 members 95 have paid
the whole amount ($27) of dues,
13 have made part payments and
16, for some reason or other, have
paid nothing. Expenditures so
far have been $10 to the Student
Council and $1,408 to the Hullabaloo. Hubbard was also authorized to have his design of the class
banner made up in time for the
class exercises. A committee was
then appointed to work on some
appropriate memorial for the class
to give the university.
ZIONIST SOCIETY.

The Johns Hopkins Zionist Society will be addressed on Tuesday, April 19, in Room 110, M. E.
Building, by Dr. Max Margolis, a
professor at Dropsie College and a
most interesting speaker. The
public is cordially invited.

Donation Of Local Sporting Goods Concern—Tournament Begun With
Over Forty Candidates
Participating.

To Be Great Send-off For Seniors—Positions On Black and Blue Jay
Open To Candidates.

The tennis tournament, which
was announced several weeks ago,
is now well under way. In response to the call for candidates
42 names were turned in. Although not as large a number as
last year, this is a very good showing considering the comparatively
early date for tennis activity.
The drawings were made and
first-match notices sent out in time
to start April 8, but due to poor
weather conditions the first match
was not played until April 14. In
this Eric Jacobsen was defeated
by Bosley Hiss. With favorable
weather conditions this week's end
should see the tournament up to
the fourth round, at least.
A set of ground rules to govern
the use of the courts is being prepared. The large number of persons wishing to use the courts and
the resulting confusion has demonstrated the need of such a set of
rules.
The Bacharach-Raisin Sporting,
Goods Company has very generously offered a $16 George Wright
racquet as a prize to the winner
of the tournament. The same firm
is further offering a considerable
reduction to J. H. U. students in
the prices of equipment.

The final edition of the Black
and Blue Jay, the Grads' number,
will appear during the latter part
of May. This issue, which is to
be devoted to Seniors and their
future, is hoped to be the best of
the year, successfully closing the
initial season of the.magazine.
In order to make the Grads'
number a real success the co-operation of the entire student-body is
prerequisite. All students are
urged to contribute and give the
Seniors a true send-off. The
Seniors are particularly requested
to aid the staff in publishing this
number, lending, as it were, the
benefits of their experience as college men.
The Black and Blue Jay board
wishes to call attention to the general spring competition for the
editorial, art and business staff
which has been recently opened. A
number of positions are available
and a splendid opportunity is
opened to men who desire to win
positions on the staff.

"Migration Of Birds" To Be Subject
Of Lecture Friday.

Dr. Harry C. Oberholser, of the
Smithsonian Institution, Washington, D. C., will address the
Scientific Club on "The Migration
of Birds" on Friday, April 22, in
the lecture room of the Mechanical Engineer Building (Room
110).
Dr. Oberholser is recognized the
world over as an authority on
bird-life, and has visited practically every part of the United
States while engaged in the extensive field work necessary to his
studies. He has recently completed a cruise on Government vessels, undertaken for the purpose
of studying the habits of sea-birds
(in particular the habits of gulls).
Dr. Oberholser has written voluminously on ornithological subjects,
and has given courses of lectures
in the American University at
Washington.
The student-body and the general public are cordially invited to
attend this lecture, which will begin promptly at 12.30 o'clock and
will end before 1 o'clock. Members of the Audubon Society are
especially urged to be present.
The Scientific Club intends in
the near future to inaugurate a
series of popular'science meetings
for the general public, in addition
to the noon meetings which cater
particularly to the interests of,the
undergraduate student. The officers will be glad to receive suggestions as to topics and speakers.

R. 0. T. C. DANCE TO BE HELD
APRIL 29.

Journey To Western Maryland Under
Leadership Of Dr. Schwartz.
Turner Goes On The Stage
With "Oh, Daddy"
Company.

According to all reports the
annual Easter geology trip was a
decided success.
Leaving the city Easter Monday the geologists arrived at Blue
Ridge Summit at 11.30 A. M.
After an unsuccessful attempt to
wreck Sprankle's busses, they
reached Pen-Mar.
In the vicinity of Key Rock the
fossil-hunters proceeded to search
for specimens. After a short time
exclamations were heard from the
neighborhood of Goldstein and
Knecht, who were seen kneeling
upon a level spot closely scanning
the marks on two small, square
fossils. Upon close examination,
however, the telltale spots and the
fervent sigh "seven" from Goldie
revealed them to be only the common everyday variety of "Alabama agates."
After digging coal, uncovering
rare specimens, and racing Dr.
Schwartz, who has held the cup
for the Cumberland derby for 10
years, the collegians retired to
Cumberland and visited the "Oh,
Daddy" show, where the chorus,
assisted by Tubby Turner, rendered "I haven't read it yet."
From there the merry-makers
retired to a "jazz hall" with most
of "Oh, Daddy." After the wrestling matches, in which Bill Randall starred, the gang "turned in."
"Goldie" when he awoke in the
morning,'
found that he had been
awarded several lemon meringue
pies—spread in a heavy film on
the lining of his suit.
However, the trip was declared
a success both geologically and
"hell-raiscally." Bubbling over
with the usual Easter trip yarns
the trippers arrived back in the
city.
To a mere student "Papa, buy
me a pool table," "Fine day for
it" and "It won't be long now"
mean nothing—but just ask a
geologist.
And don't fail to hear Steck's
song,"Whose little baby are you?"

The R. O. T. C. dance should be
a great success. It will be held
on April 29 at 9 P. M. and the
price of admission will be $2 a
couple. The affair will be informal
and uniforms will not be worn,
so the lowliest private and the
highest commissioned officer will
enter the competition on equal
terms. Tickets may be obtained
from company commanders and
from Whittington, Hall and Wilkinson. Young's orchestra has been
obtained for the occasion, so good
music and plenty of it will be
available. Major Garey, Captains
McMurray and Williams and the
officers who are visiting the university will be present. Dean and

FRESHMEN LOSE TIGHT GAME TO
CITY.

Playing errorless ball and making as many hits as their opponents the Freshmen lost to City
College at Strauss Field on Friday
by the score of 5 to 3. Inability
to profit by the breaks of the game
and some poor base-running lost
the game for the Freshmen. The
Freshmen presented a far superior team to that which played
Mount St. Josephs two "weeks ago,
and it was easy to see that they
were more than a match for City
if they had only been able to make
use of their opportunities. Ellicott
pitched for the Freshmen and
struck out eight men. He was always master of the game, except
in the first inning, when two bases
on balls and a triple by Katzenberger gave City two runs. Spinney, who pitched for City, although
a trifle wild, also twirled a good
game, having lots of steam and
plenty of curves. He scored again
for City on a drive to center by
Slingluff, making the score 3 to 0.
Ellicott brought in the Freshmen's
first run by scoring on Donnetel's
drive to left field. With two men
on the bases in the seventh it
looked like two runs for the Freshmen when Broumel hit a screeching drive over third, but Miller, of
City, made a wonder one-hand
stab, doubling his man at third.
City scored again in the eighth on
a bunt which Hutzler played foul,
and in the ninth on a wild throw
to third by •Ellicott. The Freshmen got their other two runs in the
eight and ninth also, McCubbin
driving' Goldsmith in from third
and Strouse scoring on a long fly
to left field by Broumel. For City
Katzenberger and Miller were the
stars; the former turning three
seemingly home runs into outs by
wonderful catches, and the latter
playing his position at third in fine
style and making two hits. Strouse
and Hutzler played well in the
field for the Freshmen, while Goldsmith, McCubbin and Donnetel hit
the ball hard.
The Wednesday classes on China
and Japan, under the auspices of
the Association, have proved very
popular. Both Mr. Li, of Tientsin, who is lecturing on China,
and Mr. Ibara, of Uwajima, who
is lecturing on Japan, show an infinite knowledge of their subjects.
Anyone interested in these countries as to their political, economic, commercial, educational or
religious aspects will find these
lectures most beneficial.

TRACK TEAM MEETS DISAPPOINTING REVERSE—
ALSO RAN WITH NAVY
AND DELAWARE
Hopkins' track team was outclassed in its triangular meet
with Delaware and Navy at Annapolis. The Navy piled up 60
points, Delaware collected 36
points and Hopkins received 4.
Edwards in the quarter, Somerville in the half, Wood in the high
hurdles and Aaronson in the low
hurdles scored Hopkins' 4 points
by placing third in their events.
For the rest, Navy and Delaware
presented runners too fast, weight
men to strong and jumpers too
dexterous.

Muller Addresses Field Club.

The Hopkins Field Club, which
met Wednesday, held one of the
most interesting sessions of the
term. During the first half hour
of the meeting, J. F. Muller, '24,
addressed the members of the club,
relating some of his experiences
along the Mississippi River while
doing research work with freshwater clams for the button-making
industry. The remainder of the
hour was given over to H. T.

Folger, a graduate student, who
spoke on the "Nesting Habits of
the Red Horse."
The Red Horse is a specie of
fish, somewhat resembling the
sucker, and valuable as food,
found in the Mississippi River and
streams of the Mississippi Valley.
Mr. Folger described in detail the
method of catching the Red Horse,
which is protected by law, and
then told of its nesting habits.
Both lectures were interesting and
educational, and it is hoped that

the club may be able to have more

of them.
